### *An overview of the involvement of nodes in Mentha L. sp propagation*                                             

![**Figure 1.** *Mentha* **L.** *sp.* **(Mint)**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 221207.png){fig-align="left"}
Mint (*Mentha* L. *sp.*) classification (USDA Plants database, n.d): **Kingdom:** *Plantae*- Plant **Subkingdom:** *Tracheobionta*- Vascular plant **Superdivision:** *Spermatophyta*- Seed plant **Division:** *Magnoliophyta*- Flowering plant **Class:** *Magnoliopsida*- Dicotyledon **Subclass:** *Asteridae* **Order:** *Lamiale* **Family:** *Lamiaceae* Martinov- Mint family **Genus:** *Mentha* L.
Mint (Mentha L.) is a flowering plant whose physiology and genetics allows it to be easily multiplied and nursed by novice gardeners (like myself). I don’t consider myself to have much of a green thumb but, this **angiosperm** (Prakash et al., 2016) is definitely helping my image! In this article we will explore an overview of why these little guys are so viable in water and how the molecular mechanisms of nodes in conjunction with the plant’s vegetative organs facilitate successful propagation in water. Before getting into the workings of plant nodes we must first establish vital context and for this we will take a bird’s eye view of the plant and gradually zoom in, until we get to the molecular mechanisms as the article(s) progress. Nodes are located on the stems of most plants; stems, leaves and roots are all referred to as vegetative tissue (Rost et al., 1984). Vegetative organs of plants are the drivers of nutrition and growth; they are not responsible for reproductive processes however, they collectively prepare the plant to fulfil its reproductive cycle.  Roots absorb water and minerals from the growth media (soil, water, agar, etc.); ![**Figure 2. Mint roots following propagation.**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 221226.png){fig-align="left"} leaves facilitate photosynthetic processes; ![**Figure 3. Mint leaves (removed from stem for water propagation)**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 221245.png){fig-align="left"} stems transport nutrients and water between organs as well as “sprout” new leaves and flowers; ![**Figure 4. Mint stems (clipped from plant for propagation)**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220030.png){fig-align="left"} the shoot apex is the origin of leaf formation as well as all new cells on the plant’s shoot; ![**Figure 5. Shoot apex of mint shoot.** ](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220056.png){fig-align="left"} the root apex produces all new cells on the plant’s root. ![**Figure 6. Mint root apex.** ](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220119.png){fig-align="left"} Now that we’ve set the macroscopic stage, we can adjust our focus to the star of this article: the node. Have you stared at a plant long enough to notice how its leaves grow on its stem? They vary by plant, however leaves are generally derived by nodal cells at variable intervals on the plant’s stem. The lengths of these intervals are not necessarily standard, but specific to the plant in question. **The location where leaves protrude from the stem is called a node** (Rost et al., 1984). The space between two nodes is called an **internode** (Rost et al., 1984). ![**Figure 7. Mint nodes (blue), mint internodes (red).**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220140.png){fig-align="left"} Nodal cells are considered to be **meristematic** (undifferentiated) (Buchanan et al., 2015), this indicates that some factor can influence its functionality.  In the instance of this mint propagation experiment series,  the removal of lower leaves ![**Figure 8. Mint stem cuttings with lower leaves removed**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220223.png){fig-align="left"}  and water submersion of those stems ![**Figure 9. Mint stem cuttings submerged in water for propagation**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220306.png){fig-align="left"} will trigger signals for root formation (differentiation) mechanisms at the exposed nodes.  ![**Figure 10. Roots grown from propagated stem nodes (Mint).**](images/Screenshot 2024-07-22 220326.png){fig-align="left"} These nodal cells were influenced by the mint’s vegetative tissue, namely the leaves and shoot apex, to initiate root formation in order for successful propagation to occur. Next week we will continue our molecular investigation of Mentha L. sp. propagation; in the subsequent posts we will adjust our lenses to understand the intricate mechanics of Mint propagation in water. 

**Questions to ponder until next time:** 1. What exactly are leaves? 2. Why do they need light? 3. Why does the light requirement vary by plant? 4. Where does the energy harvested through light ultimately go? Take care, Mpule Clarke.

**References** Buchanan, B. B., Gruissem, W., & Jones, R. L. (2015). Biochemistry and molecular biology of plants. John Wiley & Sons. Prakash, O., Chandra, M., Pant, A., & Rawat, D. (2016). Mint (Mentha spicata L.) Oils. In Elsevier eBooks (pp. 561–572). https://doi.org/10.1016/b978-0-12-416641-7.00064-x Rost, T. L., Barbour, M. G., Thornton, R. M., Weier, T. E., & Stocking, C. R. (n.d.). Botany: A brief introduction to plant biology. Wiley. USDA Plants Database. (n.d.). https://plants.usda.gov/home/classification/45882
